name: Cold Tanuki Udon
description: A quick summer lunch: Cold Tanuki Udon—refreshing cold udon drizzled in umami mentsuyu and topped with cucumber, tomatoes, tenkasu, wakame, and egg.

video.name: How to Make Cold Tanuki Udon (Recipe) 冷やしたぬきうどんの作り方（レシピ）
video.description:
Cool off with this refreshing and delicious cold udon drizzled in umami mentsuyu and topped with cucumber, tomatoes, tenkasu, wakame, and egg.

For the complete recipe:
http://www.justonecookbook.com/recipes/cold-tanuki-udon/

Ingredients:

⅓ cup Metnsuyu (dilute 2-3 times based on preference) (Homemade Tsuyu recipe: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cGbKa3_pzRk)
2 packages udon (I usually buy frozen “Sanuki Udon”)

Topping
2 tsp. wakame seaweed
1 scallion/green onion
1 Japanese or Persian cucumber
2 inch daikon radish (green top part of daikon tastes sweeter)
½ cup Tenkasu/Agedama (Tempura bits)
1 soft/hard-boiled egg
4 grape tomatoes
¼ tsp. roasted white sesame seeds
wasabi

Music courtesy of Audio Network: "Asturias"
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Check out my blog: http://www.justonecookbook.com/

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
❀ Follow Just One Cookbook ❀
Google+: https://plus.google.com/u/0/+NamikoChen/
Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/justonecookbook
Twitter: https://twitter.com/#!/justonecookbook
Pinterest: http://pinterest.com/justonecookbook/
Instagram: http://instagram.com/justonecookbook
------------------------------------------------------------------------

recipeIngredient: ⅓ cup mentsuyu (concentrated noodle soup base)
2 inches daikon radish ((the green top part of daikon tastes sweeter and less bitter))
1  soft or hard-boiled egg ((sliced in half))
¼ tsp toasted white sesame seeds

recipeInstructions.text: Gather all the ingredients. If you are going to make the mentsuyu from scratch, you can follow my recipe.
recipeInstructions.name: Gather all the ingredients. If you are going to make the mentsuyu from scratch, you can follow my recipe.

recipeInstructions.text: Put 2 tsp dried wakame seaweed in a small bowl and soak for 15 minutes. After soaking, queeze the water out and set aside.
recipeInstructions.name: Put 2 tsp dried wakame seaweed in a small bowl and soak for 15 minutes. After soaking, queeze the water out and set aside.

recipeInstructions.text: Peel 1 Japanese or Persian cucumber (leave some skin for a striped pattern) and thinly slice diagonally. Then, cut into julienne strips and set aside.
recipeInstructions.name: Peel 1 Japanese or Persian cucumber (leave some skin for a striped pattern) and thinly slice diagonally. Then, cut into julienne strips and set aside.

recipeInstructions.text: Peel the skin from 2 inches daikon radish and grate the daikon. Squeeze the water out and set aside.
recipeInstructions.name: Peel the skin from 2 inches daikon radish and grate the daikon. Squeeze the water out and set aside.

recipeInstructions.text: Bring a large pot of water to a boil for 2 servings udon noodles. My favorite udon is the frozen Sanuki udon. Blanch the frozen udon noodles in boiling water for 1 minute (no need to defrost).  If you use dry noodles, follow the package instructions. Remove udon from boiling water and cool in an ice bath. Wait until it cools completely and drain.
recipeInstructions.name: Bring a large pot of water to a boil for 2 servings udon noodles. My favorite udon is the frozen Sanuki udon. Blanch the frozen udon noodles in boiling water for 1 minute (no need to defrost).  If you use dry noodles, follow the package instructions. Remove udon from boiling water and cool in an ice bath. Wait until it cools completely and drain.

recipeInstructions.text: To make the sauce, add ⅓ cup mentsuyu (concentrated noodle soup base). My mentsuyu recipe should be diluted about 2–3 times depending on your preference. If you use store-bought mentsuyu, read the directions to see if you can use it “straight” (no need to dilute) or if it should be diluted 2 or 3 times. Add ice cubes to keep the mentsuyu cool.
recipeInstructions.name: To make the sauce, add ⅓ cup mentsuyu (concentrated noodle soup base). My mentsuyu recipe should be diluted about 2–3 times depending on your preference. If you use store-bought mentsuyu, read the directions to see if you can use it “straight” (no need to dilute) or if it should be diluted 2 or 3 times. Add ice cubes to keep the mentsuyu cool.

recipeInstructions.text: Serve the udon on the plate/bowl. Divide and add the toppings—the wakame, the cucumber strips, ½ cup tenkasu/agedama (tempura scraps), 1 soft or hard-boiled egg cut in half, and 4 cherry tomatoes. Sprinkle with ¼ tsp toasted white sesame seeds and the sliced green onions. Serve at the table with the mentsuyu and wasabi on the side. Pour the mentsuyu (sauce) on top and enjoy!
recipeInstructions.name: Serve the udon on the plate/bowl. Divide and add the toppings—the wakame, the cucumber strips, ½ cup tenkasu/agedama (tempura scraps), 1 soft or hard-boiled egg cut in half, and 4 cherry tomatoes. Sprinkle with ¼ tsp toasted white sesame seeds and the sliced green onions. Serve at the table with the mentsuyu and wasabi on the side. Pour the mentsuyu (sauce) on top and enjoy!

review.reviewBody:
Hi Nami,

You don't mention where to use the wasabi? Is it just used as a condiment and stirred into the soup to taste before eating?

My family loves almost any recioe with udon, but I wasn't sure if they would like a cold dish. I needed to make the Mentsuyu myself, but the only ingredient I couldn't find was kombu since my usual store didn't have any.  I couldn't tell the exact name of the seaweed I bought from the main Asian market in town, but it seemed to work well.  I at least managed to make it strong enough that it definitely needed to be diluted. But I wasn't sure if I had diluted enough because it was still quite strong by itself. Yet once added to the udon and vegetables, it was perfect.

おいしい

I wonder how well this would pack for a work lunch? Curious about how well udon would hold up. I would assume to keep the tenkasu separate until serving to retain its crunch.
Hi, http://amzn.to/1mPPqL9 looks different from the one in this recipe. The one in your recipe looks nicer. Do you mind posting what brand it is? Thanks.
